DataElement.preferredName: Known Primary Uterus Malignant Neoplasm Confirmation With Endometrial Biopsy Eligibility Determination Yes No Not Applicable Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: An eligibility indicator asking whether pre-operative primary uterine cancer was confirmed by an endometrial biopsy._The act of determining if a subject is suitable for enrollment in a study according specific protocol criteria and procedures with permissible values of yes/no/not applicable.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Known Primary Uterus Malignant Neoplasm Confirmation With Endometrial Biopsy Eligibility Determination
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: An eligibility indicator asking whether pre-operative primary uterine cancer was confirmed by an endometrial biopsy._The act of determining if a subject is suitable for enrollment in a study according specific protocol criteria and procedures.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Known Primary Uterus Malignant Neoplasm Confirmation With Endometrial Biopsy Eligibility Determination
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Recognized, familiar, or within the scope of knowledge.:Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.:A hollow, thick-walled, muscular organ located within the pelvic cavity of a woman. Within the uterus the fertilized egg implants and the fetus develops during pregnancy.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.:Having been established or verified.:Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.:Removal of tissue from the endometrial cavity for microscopic examination.:Criteria to determine eligibility of patients for medical care programs and services.

Concepts.definition: Recognized, familiar, or within the scope of knowledge.
Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.
A hollow, thick-walled, muscular organ located within the pelvic cavity of a woman. Within the uterus the fertilized egg implants and the fetus develops during pregnancy.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.
Removal of tissue from the endometrial cavity for microscopic examination.
The act of determining if a subject is suitable for enrollment in a study according specific protocol criteria and procedures.

A basic or essential attribute shared by all members of a class.
